The effect of Ag as a promoter for Ru/CeO2 catalysts in ammonia synthesis Jianxin Lin ⁎ Liuming Zhang Ziqing Wang Jun Ni Rong Wang Kemei Wei National Engineering Research Center of Chemical Fertilizer Catalyst, Fuzhou University, Fuzhou 350002, Fujian, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +86 591 83731234 8102. Graphical abstract Highlights ► Silver is a very efficient promoter for Ru/CeO2 catalyst in ammonia synthesis. ► Silver can improve the reduction profiles of ceria by enhance the SMSI effect. ► Silver can weaken the competition of hydrogen and nitrogen adsorbed on Ru surface. ► The work function of Ru metal was decreased by silver loading. A series of Ag–Ru/CeO2 catalysts were prepared by conventional impregnation methods and characterized by XRD, BET, XPS, H2-TPR, H2-TPD-MS, and N2-TPD. The activity test shows that ammonia concentration of the catalyst with 6% Ag is 9.4% at 10MPa, 10,000h−1, 400°C, which is 22% higher than that of Ru/CeO2. Such high catalytic activity was ascribed to three effects: electron donating property of partially reduced CeO2−x to Ru metal, the low workfunction of Ru atoms and the less competitive adsorbed between hydrogen and nitrogen on Ru atoms derived from the synergetic effect between Ag and Ru. Keywords Ruthenium catalyst Silver SMSI Ammonia synthesis CeO2 1 Introduction It is well known that promoters played a very important role in Ru based catalysts. Many promoters such as alkali metal [1–3], alkali-earth metal [4–7], rare earth metal and their oxides or hydroxides [8,9] have been widely investigated with the aim of preparing a Ru-based catalyst with high activity. Different Ru catalysts with different supports and promoters have different kinetic features for ammonia synthesis [10]. But the rate-determining step of ammonia synthesis for Ru based catalysts was generally accepted to be the nitrogen dissociative adsorption [11–13]. It has been reported that the competitive adsorption between nitrogen and hydrogen on Ru surface was another reason for limiting the rates of ammonia synthesis [14]. Hydrogen seems to be more strongly adsorbed on Ru atoms surface, the Ru surface would be almost covered with hydrogen atoms [9]. The rate-determining nitrogen activation process will be inhibited by the strong adsorption of hydrogen [15]. The role of alkali and earth metals promoters is considered to donate electrons to Ru surface, where nitrogen is activated effectively [16], but it is not likely to release the strong hydrogen adsorption [17]. Samarium can reduce the adsorption of hydrogen [8,9], while it seems incapable to contribute enough electrons to accelerate the dissociation of nitrogen [15]. So an ideal promoter for Ru catalysts should be devised both donates enough electrons to Ru metal and can reduce hydrogen adsorption. Ceria is one of the most effective supports for ammonia synthesis. Some researchers found that partially reduced CeO2−x can donate electrons to Ru, which is useful to promote the cleavage of NN triple bond [18,19]. Zhang et al. [20] found that Ag can enhance the reduction properties of ceria on studying Ag–CeO2 catalyst, and silver does not adsorb or react with hydrogen [21]. Thus, the silver could be an effective promoter for Ru/CeO2 catalyst in ammonia synthesis. For better understanding the effect of silver on Ru/CeO2, a series of Ag promoted catalysts (Ag–Ru/CeO2) were prepared by conventional impregnation method. The characterization such as the specific surface area (BET), X-ray diffraction (XRD), temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), N2-TPD and H2-TPD-MS was carried out to get a closer insight into the Ag–Ru/CeO2 catalyst. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of Ru catalysts Ru/CeO2 catalyst was prepared by using co-precipitation (CP) methods. All samples used in this method were designed to load 4wt% Ru. Ce(NO3)3·6H2O was dissolved in 100ml distilled water. After vigorous stirring at 60°C for 0.5h, the aqueous solution of KOH and K2RuO4 was added drop wise to the aqueous mixture, and the obtained black suspension was kept under stirring at 60°C for 1h. After cooling to room temperature, the resulting precipitate was centrifuged and washed with distilled water for three times, and then the precipitate was dried at 120°C for 12h and calcined in the mixture of H2 and N2 at 500°C for 2h. The catalyst was labeled as Ru/CeO2. The Ru/CeO2 was carried out by incipient-wetness impregnation method with silver nitrate. The catalyst with 12–16 mesh was labeled as Agx%–Ru/CeO2 and x was the adding amount of silver in ceria. 2.2 Measurement of activity for ammonia synthesis The catalyst activity for ammonia synthesis was measured in a stainless steel reactor. Before testing, the catalysts were activated in a flowing gas mixture of 75% H2 and 25% N2 from ambient temperature to 500°C at 1°Cmin−1 (kept at 200, 300, 450, and 500°C for 2h, respectively) and then stabilized under the reaction conditions (i.e.10MPa, 400°C, 10,000h−1, and H2/N2 volume ratio of 3) for more than 2h. The ammonia concentration in the effluent was determined by a chemical titration method [8,22]. 2.3 Characterization XRD analysis was carried out on a PANalytical X’pert pro diffractometer system, using Co Ka radiation (0.1789nm). N2 physisorption was measured on the adsorption instrument Nova Win2. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were collected using a Physical Electronics Quantum 2000 spectrometer with a monochromatic Al–Ka source (Ka=1486.6eV). Charge referencing was measured against adventitious carbon (C1s peak at 284.6eV). Temperature-programmed reduction of the sample was pretreated in argon (30mlmin−1) to 150°C for 60min, then the temperature was increased by 10°Cmin−1 up to 800°C by a temperature programmable controller in the flow of 10vol% H2/Ar (30mlmin−1) (all the samples were 0.1g). Temperature-programmed desorption of hydrogen was treated at 500°C for 2h under a flow of hydrogen (flow rate of 30mlmin−1). After being cooled down to room temperature, the catalyst was purged in flow of argon (30mlmin−1) for 1h. The H2-TPD experiment was performed by sample heating at a rate of 10°Cmin−1 from room temperature to 800°C under an argon flow (20mlmin−1). The effluent gas was analyzed with a mass spectrometer (all the samples were 0.1g). The N2-TPD experiment was performed by sample heating at a rate of 10°Cmin−1 from room temperature to 750°C under helium flow (20mlmin−1). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 XRD characterization The XRD patterns of Agx%–Ru/CeO2 catalysts are shown in Fig. 1 . One can see that the samples (a–d) have distinct crystal phases of fluorite oxide type CeO2 [8]. And no separate reflections from Ag or its oxide until the content of silver up to 8%, this may be attributed to that the silver species were smaller in diameter than the detection limit (4nm) of the diffractometer or that large Ag particles (>4nm) were too scarce to produce detectable diffraction signals. In the sample with high Ag content (8%), a small broad peak corresponding to metal Ag (2θ =44.58 (Co Ka)) can be seen in Fig. 1(e). Similar results have been achieved by Zhang et al. based on studying Ag/CeO2 catalyst [20]. And they found that the diffraction lines intensify with the Ag loading increases, indicating that Ag particles size increasing gradually with the increasing Ag loading. 3.2 The surface area and catalytic activity As shown in Table 1 , the surface area over Agx%–Ru/CeO2 reduced gradually with increasing Ag loading, the results could be accepted by considering that the presence of Ag would fill the small pores in catalysts surface as shown in Fig. 2 . But the catalytic activity over Agx–Ru/CeO2 catalysts increased greatly with increasing Ag loading. Under 10MPa, 10,000h−1, 400°C, the sample with 6% silver showed the highest NH3 concentration (9.4%), which is 22% higher than that of Ru/CeO2 (7.7%), and also much higher than those of Ru/CeO2 catalysts promoted with anther promoters under the same conditions, such as Ru/Sm2O3–CeO2 (7.8%) [8]. Obviously, the activity increased with increasing Ag content up to a certain value, and then decreased upon further increasing Ag loading. Above results suggest that the surface area of catalysts has little effect on the catalytic activity. 3.3 Reduction behaviors of the Agx–Ru/CeO2 catalysts The H2-TPR patterns are shown in Fig. 3 and the data are summarized in Table 2 . It is evidently that both Ru/CeO2 and Ag/CeO2 samples exhibit two different stages during hydrogen reduction in temperature range of 40–800°C. The low temperature peak is attributed to the reduction of dispersed metal species, and the much higher temperature peak is assigned to the surface oxygen species of ceria [8,20]. Compared with the reduction temperature of CeO2 (435°C), the temperature of the maximum at high temperature peak apparently shifts to lower temperature at the presence of Ru or Ag (347 and 267°C, respectively), which clearly implied that the presence of Ru or Ag accelerated the reduction of ceria. Many researches have attributed such shifts to the strong metal–support interaction (SMSI) effect [19,23,24]. Thus, it was reasonable to propose that Ag or Ru enables interaction with CeO2 support (SMSI) and can accelerate the reduction of CeO2 [8,19]. In addition, the reduction temperature of Ag/CeO2 (267°C) is much lower than that of Ru/CeO2 catalyst (347°C), suggesting that the interaction between Ag and CeO2 is much stronger than that between Ru and CeO2. From the reduction profiles of Ag–Ru/CeO2 catalyst, it clearly shows that only one peak of hydrogen consumption appear in the low temperature range of 50–200°C. The data of H2-TPR is given in Table 2, it can be seen that the total amount of hydrogen consumed during the reduction of Ag/CeO2 and Ru/CeO2 catalyst (62.25 and 73.66ml/g, respectively) is much less than that of Ag–Ru/CeO2 catalyst (151.6ml/g). Obviously, the coexistence of Ru and Ag could further enhance the SMSI effect, and much more reduced ceria was produced. Partially reduced ceria was known to be an n-type semiconductor[25], a mobile electron in CeO2 can be donated to ruthenium, which can promote the cleavage of NN triple bond [18] and enhances the catalytic activity for ammonia synthesis [8,26]. Similar results have been obtained from previous literatures [8,24]. Results of H2-TPR show that silver promoter can improve the activity of Ag–Ru/CeO2 catalyst for ammonia synthesis by facilitating the reduction of cerium oxide and donating electrons to Ru. 3.4 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy Fig. 4 shows the Ag 3d and Ru 3d spectra measured from Ag–Ru/CeO2 and Ru/CeO2 catalyst. The Ag 3d spectrum consists of a spin–orbit coupling doublet, with binding energies of 367.7eV for Ag 3d5/2 and 373.7eV for Ag 3d3/2, respectively. The binding energy of the Ag 3d5/2 peak located at 367.7eV demonstrating that Ag is present in the +1 oxidation according to previous literatures [27,28]. Actually, no XRD diffraction peaks corresponding to Ag2O were observed as shown in Fig. 1. However, the XPS results indicate that silver exists on the surface of the Ag–Ru/CeO2 catalyst in the form of +1 oxidation state. The generation of Ag+ species could be attributed to the strong interaction between silver and CeO2, through which the active oxygen species on the surface of CeO2 was transferred to silver and oxidized into Ag+. According to the results of Ru 3d XPS, the Eb(Ru 3d5/2) values of Ru/CeO2 (a) and Ag–Ru/CeO2 (b) catalysts were 281.86eV and 281.26eV, respectively, which were higher than that of Ru 3d5/2 (280.2eV) in Ru metal [22] and Ru 3d5/2 (280.6eV) in RuO2 [29]. This shift has been ascribed to Ru submit into the lattice of ceria in the XPS study of Ce1−x Ru x O2 catalyst [29]. Compared with the binding energy values of Ru(3d5/2) in Ag–Ru/CeO2 and Ru/CeO2 catalyst, it is found that the Eb(Ru/3d5/2) slightly shifts to lower value at the presence of silver. The similar negative shift was also found based on studying Ru–Cs/MgO catalyst [30]. It is clearly implied that the working function of Ru has been decreased. Lowing the work function for a transition metal as a result of its coating with an alkali metal–oxygen film has been reported in many papers [31–33]. There are two different ways to explain such negative shift. One is that the formation of an electric double layer with the participation of Ag+ cations and surface Ru particles at the interface between Ru particles and Ag2O coverings. Another explanation is that the Ag promoter donates electrons to ruthenium to cause the negative charging of metal particles as the same as alkali metal (change transfer mechanism) [34,35]. If the nanoparticle becomes charged, the extra charge will distribute according to the electronic structure and it is very speculative to argue that this will be localize on the surface Ru atoms. The same goes for a lowering of the workfunction. Even though the experimental data are not sufficient to conclude unambiguously the reasons for this change in the initial state of support Ru under the influence of Ag promoter, the effect of Ag promoter on Ru-based catalysts may be just as the effect of alkali metal or an alkali metal compound. Both suggested effects (negative charge transfer or lowering the work function of Ru) could result in a more efficient charge transfer to the antibonding orbitals of adsorbed N2 molecules and promote N2 dissociation that is the rate-determining step of ammonia synthesis. Thus, the samples with Ag loading have higher catalytic activity for ammonia synthesis. 3.5 N2-TPD and H2-TPD measurement To further understand the effect of silver on Ru/CeO2, the N2-TPD experiments were carried out and the result was shown in Fig. 5 . One can see that the intensity of low temperature peak of nitrogen desorption has hardly change and the same as that of CeO2, suggesting that the reduced ceria could adsorb nitrogen. Therefore, the low and high temperatures desorption peaks for all samples are attributed to the nitrogen desorption of reduced ceria and dispersed Ru phase respectively. Lots of papers have proven that the interface between Ru and reduced support (such as CeO2−x , BaZrO3−x , BaCeO3−x and Ta2O3−x ) was an efficient site for activation of N2 [19,26,36,37]. Most recent literature also thought the presence the interface existing in Ru and reduced promoter (such as CsO2+x and BaO1+x ) was the main active sites for ammonia synthesis in Ba–Ru/AC, Cs–Ru/AC and Cs–Ru/MgO systems [38–40]. Obviously, the nature of the Ru/support or Ru/promoter interface is a major control factor of ammonia synthesis. In our present study, we also found that the intensity of high-temperature peak increased gradually with the increasing Ag loading, indicating that the addition of Ag could increase the amount of adsorbed nitrogen on Ru surface and improve the ability of active N2. That is to say, the presence of Ag promoter would increase the amount of active sites compared with Ru/CeO2 catalyst, which is good accord with the results of H2-TPR in the present study. Fig. 6 shows the H2-TPD profiles of CeO2, Ag6%–Ru/CeO2, Ag2%–Ru/CeO2 and Ru/CeO2 samples. According our previous study [8], there are two hydrogen desorption peaks located at 75°C and about 190°C, which are respectively attributed to the hydrogen desorption of dispersed Ru phase and reduced ceria. Unlike the profiles of N2-TPD, the intensity of hydrogen desorption peak reduced with the increasing of Ag content. In theory, the more reduced ceria, the more the hydrogen adsorbed on ceria surface. On the contrary, the intensity of the hydrogen adsorbed peak declines dramatically. But it can be accepted by considering that Ag promoter loading could result in the reduction of the adsorbed sites and surface area. Though the O vacancy created by reduced ceria can adsorb hydrogen, Ag could interacted with O vacancy of CeO2−x [41–43], occupied O vacancy would not adsorb hydrogen, so the intensity of hydrogen desorption peak reduced with Ag loading. Additionally, it is well known that suppression of H2 chemisorption is an important property for the mental/oxides systems with SMSI effect [44]. This SMSI effect would be further improved in Ru/CeO2 system due to the addition of Ag promoter. Of course, the ability of absorption of H2 also decreased with the improvement of the SMSI effect. As a result, the intensity of hydrogen desorption peak of Ag–Ru/CeO2 catalyst decreased gradually and released some active sites for activation of nitrogen with increasing Ag loading. Thus, compared with the profiles of adsorbed hydrogen and nitrogen on the same Ru atoms, it is clearly observed that the mount of hydrogen adsorbed decreased while nitrogen adsorbed increased, implying that the competitive adsorption between hydrogen and nitrogen on Ru metal surface is reduced. Obviously, all the changes in the adsorption/desorption properties of feedstock gas are advantageous to ammonia synthesis. Here combining with the characterization results and catalytic data provided clear evidence that at least lies in the following three factors account for the reason why Ag–Ru/CeO2 exhibits superior activity for ammonia synthesis to Ru/CeO2 catalyst. First, the presence of Ag improve the reduction profiles of Ru/CeO2 catalysts, partially reduced ceria tend to donate electrons to Ru or modify the Ru surface morphologically and thus created the active site for N2 activation directly [8,18,19]. Second, corresponding XPS results showed the strong mental–support interaction (SMSI) effect can result in the low workfunction of Ru atoms, which may be an important reason for such high catalytic activity. Third, some kind of synergistic effect between Ag and Ru could be formed when some of Ag species was left on Ru surface. This effect would reduce hydrogen adsorption and release much more sites for N2 adsorption that was considered to be the rate-limiting step for ammonia synthesis [15,24]. Therefore, at high pressures and low reaction temperature, the catalytic activity of Ru/CeO2 catalysts was improved greatly by silver loading. 4 Conclusions The silver was first used as promoter for Ru based catalysts, and it was successfully added to the catalyst by conventional impregnation methods. At low reaction temperature (400°C), the activity of Ag–Ru/CeO2 catalyst with 6% Ag loading was 22% higher than that of the non-promoted catalyst. Catalytic activity increased with the silver content up to a certain value and then decreased with further increasing Ag loading. Silver promoter can improve the reduction of ceria through the strong metal–support interaction effect, and lower the workfunction of Ru atoms. Furthermore, silver promoter might weaken the competition of hydrogen and nitrogen adsorbed on Ru surface. Above all results demonstrate that silver is a very efficient promoter for Ru/CeO2 catalysts. coredata.dc:description: A series of Ag–Ru/CeO2 catalysts were prepared by conventional impregnation methods and characterized by XRD, BET, XPS, H2-TPR, H2-TPD-MS, and N2-TPD. The activity test shows that ammonia concentration of the catalyst with 6% Ag is 9.4% at 10MPa, 10,000h−1, 400°C, which is 22% higher than that of Ru/CeO2. Such high catalytic activity was ascribed to three effects: electron donating property of partially reduced CeO2−x to Ru metal, the low workfunction of Ru atoms and the less competitive adsorbed between hydrogen and nitrogen on Ru atoms derived from the synergetic effect between Ag and Ru.
coredata.dc:title: The effect of Ag as a promoter for Ru/CeO2 catalysts in ammonia synthesis
